sen.j: 岩船寺（がんせんじ）は京都府木津川市加茂町にある真言律宗の寺院である。
sen.e: Gansen-ji Temple is a Buddhist temple belonging to the Shingon Ritsu Sect located in Kamo-cho, Kizugawa City, Kyoto Prefecture.
Gansen-ji Temple is a Buddhist temple belonging to the Shingon Ritsu Sect located in Kamo-cho, Kizugawa City, Kyoto Prefecture.
Gansen-ji Temple is a Buddhist temple belonging to the Shingon Ritsu Sect located in Kamo-cho, Kizugawa City, Kyoto Prefecture.

sen.j: 山号は高雄山（こうゆうざん）。
sen.e: Its honorific mountain prefix is Koyuzan.
Its honorific mountain prefix is Koyuzan.
Its sango (literally, "mountain name"), which is the title prefixed to the name of a Buddhist temple, is Koyuzan.

sen.j: 本尊は阿弥陀如来。
sen.e: The principal image is Amida Nyorai.
The principal image is Amida Nyorai.
The principal image is Amida Nyorai.

sen.j: 開基（創立者）は行基と伝える。
sen.e: Legend has it that the temple was founded by Gyoki.
Legend has it that the temple was founded by Gyoki.
Legend has it that the temple was founded by Gyoki.

sen.j: アジサイの名所として知られる。
sen.e: The temple is famous for its hydrangea flowers.
The temple is famous for its hydrangea flowers.
The temple is famous for its hydrangea flowers.

sen.j: 岩船寺の名は門前にある岩船(いわふね)にちなむ。
sen.e: The name "Gansen-ji" (lit. Rock Boat Temple) is connected to the boat-shaped rock that stands in front of the main gate.
The name "Gansen-ji" (lit. Rock Boat Temple) is connected to the boat-shaped rock that stands in front of the main gate.
The name Gansen-ji (lit. Rock Boat Temple) is connected to the boat-shaped rock that stands in front of the main gate.

sen.j: 岩船寺は京都府の南端、奈良県境に近い当尾（とうの）の里に位置する。
sen.e: Gansen-ji Temple is situated in Tono-no-sato in the very south of Kyoto Prefecture near to the border of Nara Prefecture.
Gansen-ji Temple is situated in Tono-no-sato in the very south of Kyoto Prefecture near to the border of Nara Prefecture.
Gansen-ji Temple is situated in Tono-no-sato in the very south of Kyoto Prefecture near to the border of Nara Prefecture.

sen.j: この地区は行政的には京都府に属するが、地理的には奈良に近く、文化的にも南都の影響が強いとされている。
sen.e: Administratively the area is part of Kyoto Prefecture but is geographically close to Nara and was culturally influenced strongly by the southern capital of Nara.
Administratively the area is part of Kyoto Prefecture but is geographically close to Nara and was culturally influenced strongly by the southern capital of Nara.
Administratively the area is part of Kyoto Prefecture but is geographically close to Nara and was culturally influenced strongly by the southern capital of Nara.

sen.j: 近くには九体阿弥陀仏で知られる浄瑠璃寺がある。
sen.e: Nearby is Joruri-ji Temple, known for its nine statues of Amida.
Nearby is Joruri-ji Temple, known for its nine statues of Amida.
Nearby is Joruri-ji Temple, known for its nine statues of Amida.

sen.j: 岩船寺、浄瑠璃寺付近には当尾石仏群と称される鎌倉時代を中心とした石仏（多くは自然の岩壁に直接刻んだ磨崖仏）や石塔が多数残り、その中には鎌倉時代の銘記を有するものも多い。
sen.e: In the vicinity of Gansen-ji Temple and Joruri-ji Temple is the "Tono Sekibutsu-gun" which consists of numerous stone pagodas and stone Buddhist images (many having been carved directly into natural rock faces) of which most date from during the Kamakura period, including many with Kamakura period inscriptions.

In the vicinity of Gansen-ji Temple and Joruri-ji Temple is the "Tono Sekibutsu-gun" which consists of numerous stone pagodas and stone Buddhist images (many having been carved directly into natural rock faces) of which most date from during the Kamakura period, including many with Kamakura period inscriptions.

In the vicinity of Gansen-ji Temple and Joruri-ji Temple is the Tono Sekibutsu-gun which consists of numerous stone pagodas and stone Buddhist images (many having been carved directly into natural rock faces) of which most date from during the Kamakura period, including many with Kamakura period inscriptions.

sen.j: 当尾には中世には、都会の喧騒を離れて修行に専念する僧が多数居住し、多くの寺院が建てられたと言われ、今に残る石仏・石塔群はその名残りであるといわれている。
sen.e: During the middle ages, Tono was inhabited by many monks who had left the urban hustle and bustle to devote themselves to ascetic practices, and it is said that many temples were built in the area, of which the stone Buddhist images and pagodas that can be seen today are the remains.

During the middle ages, Tono was inhabited by many monks who had left the urban hustle and bustle to devote themselves to ascetic practices, and it is said that many temples were built in the area, of which the stone Buddhist images and pagodas that can be seen today are the remains.

During the middle ages, Tono was inhabited by many monks who had left the urban hustle and bustle to devote themselves to ascetic practices, and it is said that many temples were built in the area, of which the stone Buddhist images and pagodas that can be seen today are the remains.

sen.j: 岩船寺は寺伝によると天平元年（729年）に聖武天皇の発願により行基が建立したと伝わる。
sen.e: According to Gansen-ji Temple legend, it was founded in 729 by Gyoki according to the will of Emperor Shomu.
According to Gansen-ji Temple legend, it was founded in 729 by Gyoki according to the will of Emperor Shomu.
According to Gansen-ji Temple legend, it was founded in 729 by Gyoki according to the will of the Emperor Shomu.

sen.j: その後、平安時代初期の大同 (日本)元年（806年）に空海（弘法大師）の甥・智泉（ちせん）が入り、伝法灌頂（密教の儀式）の道場として報恩院を建立した。
sen.e: In the year 806 at the beginning of Heian Period, Kukai's (Kobo Daishi) nephew Chisen became chief priest and constructed Hoon-in as a seminary for conducting the Denbo Kanjo (an esoteric Buddhism rite).

In the year 806 at the beginning of Heian Period, Kukai's (Kobo Daishi) nephew Chisen became chief priest and constructed Hoon-in as a seminary for conducting the Denbo Kanjo (an esoteric Buddhism rite).

In the year 806 at the beginning of Heian period, Kukai's (Kobo Daishi) nephew Chisen became chief priest and constructed Hoon-in as a seminary for conducting the Denbo Kanjo (an esoteric Buddhism rite).

sen.j: 弘仁4年（813年）には嵯峨天皇が皇子誕生を祈念して後の仁明天皇を授かったので、嵯峨天皇の皇后が伽藍を整え、岩船寺と称するようになったという。
sen.e: After the birth of the future Emperor Ninmyo after Emperor Saga prayed at the temple for a son in the year 813, Emperor Saga's wife had a temple complex constructed and the institution was named Gansen-ji Temple.

After the birth of the future Emperor Ninmyo after Emperor Saga prayed at the temple for a son in the year 813, Emperor Saga's wife had a temple complex constructed and the institution was named Gansen-ji Temple.

After the birth of the future Emperor Ninmyo after Emperor Saga prayed at the temple for a son in the year 813, the Emperor Saga's wife had a temple complex constructed and the institution was named Gansen-ji Temple.

sen.j: 以上はあくまでも寺伝であり、中世以降の火災で古記録が失われているため、草創の正確な時期や事情ははっきりしていない。
sen.e: The above account is merely temple legend and the precise time and circumstances of the temple's founding remain unclear due to the destruction of the ancient records in a fire during the middle ages.

The above account is merely temple legend and the precise time and circumstances of the temple's founding remain unclear due to the destruction of the ancient records in a fire during the middle ages.

The above account is merely temple legend and the precise time and circumstances of the temple's founding remain unclear due to the destruction of the ancient records in a fire during the middle ages.

sen.j: なお、本尊の阿弥陀如来坐像は坐高2.8メートルを超える大作であり、像内に天慶9年（946年）の銘記があることから、遅くとも10世紀半ばには岩船寺はかなりの規模の寺院であったと推定される。
sen.e: The principal image seated statue of Amida Nyorai is large at over 2.8m in height and it is assumed from the internal inscription dating from the year 946 that Gansen-ji Temple had become an extremely large temple by the middle of the 10th century at the latest.

The principal image seated statue of Amida Nyorai is large at over 2.8m in height and it is assumed from the internal inscription dating from the year 946 that Gansen-ji Temple had become an extremely large temple by the middle of the 10th century at the latest.

The principal image seated statue of Amida Nyorai is large at over 2.8 m in height and it is assumed from the internal inscription dating from the year 946 that Gansen-ji Temple had become an extremely large temple by the middle of the 10th century at the latest.

sen.j: 承久3年（1221年）の承久の変の兵火により建物のほとんどを焼失するが、室町時代に三重塔などが再建される。
sen.e: The majority of the temple buildings were destroyed by fire in the Jokyu Disturbance of 1221 but some of the structures including the three-storey pagoda were rebuilt during the Muromachi period.
The majority of the temple buildings were destroyed by fire in the Jokyu Disturbance of 1221 but some of the structures including the three-storey pagoda were rebuilt during the Muromachi period.
The majority of the temple buildings were destroyed by fire in the Jokyu Disturbance of 1221 but some of the structures including the three-storey pagoda were rebuilt during the Muromachi period.

sen.j: 江戸時代には興福寺の末寺であった。
sen.e: Gansen-ji Temple became a branch temple of Kofuku-ji Temple in the Edo period.
Gansen-ji Temple became a branch temple of Kofuku-ji Temple in the Edo period.
Gansen-ji Temple became a branch temple of Kofuku-ji Temple in the Edo period.

sen.j: 仏塔古寺十八尊 第4番
sen.e: The 4th temple of the 18 Historical Temples with Pagodas (18 Sacred Sites of Butto-koji)
The 4th temple of the 18 Historical Temples with Pagodas (18 Sacred Sites of Butto-koji)
The 4th temple of the 18 Historical Temples with Pagodas (18 Sacred Sites of Butto-koji)

sen.j: 関西花の寺二十五霊場 第15番
sen.e: The 15th temple of the 25 Kansai Hana no Tera (the temples famous for flowers in Kansai Region)
The 15th temple of the 25 Kansai Hana no Tera (the temples famous for flowers in Kansai Region)
The 15th temple of the 25 Kansai Hana no Tera (the temples famous for flowers in Kansai Region)

sen.j: 本堂－昭和62年（1987年）に再建された建物で、平安時代の阿弥陀如来坐像が安置されている。
sen.e: Main hall: The building reconstructed in 1987 that houses the Heian period seated statue of Amida Nyorai.
Main hall: The building reconstructed in 1987 that houses the Heian period seated statue of Amida Nyorai.
Main hall: The building reconstructed in 1987 that houses the Heian period seated statue of Amida Nyorai.

sen.j: 三重塔（重要文化財）－室町時代の嘉吉2年（1442年）に建立された三重塔で、初重の内部には来迎柱を立て、須弥壇と来迎壁を設ける。
sen.e: Three-storey pagoda (Important Cultural Property): A three-story pagoda constructed in 1442 during the Muromachi period of which the ground level has raigobashira (circular pillars right and left at each corner of the Buddhist altar), a shumidan (timber altar) and a wall erected behind the shumidan the two rear raigobashira.

Three-storey pagoda (Important Cultural Property): A three-story pagoda constructed in 1442 during the Muromachi period of which the ground level has raigobashira (circular pillars right and left at each corner of the Buddhist altar), a shumidan (timber altar) and a wall erected behind the shumidan the two rear raigobashira.

Three-storey pagoda (Important Cultural Property): A three-story pagoda constructed in 1442 during the Muromachi period of which the ground level has raigobashira (circular pillars right and left at each corner of the Buddhist altar), a shumidan (timber altar) and a wall erected behind the shumidan the two rear raigobashira.

sen.j: 十三重石塔（重要文化財）－13個の笠石を積み重ねた高さ6.2ｍの十三重塔で、鎌倉時代に建立された。
sen.e: Thirteen-storey pagoda (Important Cultural Property): A 6.2 meter high thirteen-storey pagoda consisting of 13 layered coping stones that was constructed during the Kamakura period.
Thirteen-storey pagoda (Important Cultural Property): A 6.2 meter high thirteen-storey pagoda consisting of 13 layered coping stones that was constructed during the Kamakura period.
Thirteen-storey pagoda (Important Cultural Property): A 6.2 meter high thirteen-storey pagoda consisting of 13 layered coping stones that was constructed during the Kamakura period.

sen.j: 五輪塔（重要文化財）－鎌倉時代
sen.e: Five-ring pagoda (Important Cultural Property): Constructed during the Kamakura period.
Five-ring pagoda (Important Cultural Property): Constructed during the Kamakura period.
Five-ring pagoda (Important Cultural Property): Constructed during the Kamakura period.

sen.j: 石室（重要文化財）－花崗岩製。
sen.e: Stone hut (Important Cultural Property): Made from granite.
Stone hut (Important Cultural Property): Made from granite.
Stone hut (Important Cultural Property): Made from granite.

sen.j: 奥壁には不動明王像を刻み、手前左右に2本の角柱を立て、これらで寄棟屋根を支える。
sen.e: An image of Fudo Myoo is engraved in the inner wall and there are two square posts that stand to the right and left to support the hipped roof.
An image of Fudo Myoo is engraved in the inner wall and there are two square posts that stand to the right and left to support the hipped roof.
An image of Fudo Myoo is engraved in the inner wall and there are two square posts that stand to the right and left to support the hipped roof.

sen.j: 応長2年（1312年）の銘がある。
sen.e: The building includes an inscription dating it at 1312.
The building includes an inscription dating it at 1312.
The building includes an inscription dating it at 1312.

sen.j: なお、境内の裏山には白山神社と春日神社の社殿が並んで建ち、向かって左の白山神社本殿は重要文化財である（室町時代建立）。
sen.e: Hakusan-jinja Shrine and Kasuga-jinja Shrine stand on the mountain to the rear of the temple precinct, and the main sanctuary of Hakusan-jinja Shrine on the left when viewed from the front is an Important Cultural Property (constructed during the Muromachi period).

Hakusan-jinja Shrine and Kasuga-jinja Shrine stand on the mountain to the rear of the temple precinct, and the main sanctuary of Hakusan-jinja Shrine on the left when viewed from the front is an Important Cultural Property (constructed during the Muromachi period).

Hakusan-jinja Shrine and Kasuga-jinja Shrine stand on the mountain to the rear of the temple precinct, and the main sanctuary of Hakusan-jinja Shrine on the left when viewed from the front is an Important Cultural Property (constructed during the Muromachi period).

sen.j: 木造阿弥陀如来坐像 － 岩船寺の本尊。
sen.e: Wooden seated statue of Amida Nyorai: The principal image of Gansen-ji Temple.
Wooden seated statue of Amida Nyorai: The principal image of Gansen-ji Temple.

sen.j: 本堂に安置。
sen.e: Housed within the main hall.

sen.j: 坐高2.8メートルを超える大作で、像内に「□□九年」と読める墨書があり、年号の部分は判読不能だが、干支から天慶9年（946年）とわかる。
sen.e: The statue is large at over 2.8m in height and inside is an ink inscription reading "Year 9 of the XX era" in which the era name is illegible but it is known from the oriental zodiac to year 9 of the Tengyo era (946).

The statue is large at over 2.8m in height and inside is an ink inscription reading "Year 9 of the XX era" in which the era name is illegible but it is known from the oriental zodiac to year 9 of the Tengyo era (946).

sen.j: 10世紀の在銘基準作例として貴重である。
sen.e: The piece is highly valuable as an inscribed work dating from the 10th century.
The piece is highly valuable as an inscribed work dating from the 10th century.
The piece is highly valuable as an inscribed work dating from the 10th century.

sen.j: 表情は穏やかだが、体躯は全体に太造りで、平安初期彫刻から平安後期の定朝様の優美な仏像への過渡期に位置する像である。
sen.e: With a gentle facial expression yet a boldly crafted body, this is elegant Buddha statue in the Jocho style of the transition period between the early and latter parts Heian period.
With a gentle facial expression yet a boldly crafted body, this is elegant Buddha statue in the Jocho style of the transition period between the early and latter parts Heian period.

sen.j: 厨子入木造普賢菩薩像 － もと三重塔に安置。
sen.e: Wooden statue of Fugen Bosatsu in a miniature shrine: Originally housed within the three-storey pagoda.
Wooden statue of Fugen Bosatsu in a miniature shrine: Originally housed within the three-storey pagoda.

sen.j: 像高39cmの小像で平安時代後期の作である。
sen.e: The small Heian period statue stands at 39cm in height.
The small Heian period statue stands at 39cm in height.

sen.j: 正応6年（1293年）の銘がある。
sen.e: Carrying inscriptions dating from the year 1293.
Carrying inscriptions dating from the year 1293.

sen.j: JR大和路線加茂駅 (京都府)より奈良交通バス「岩船寺」下車
sen.e: Take the Nara Kotsu Bus from the JR Yamatoji Line Kamo Station (Kyoto Prefecture) and alight at "Gansenji" bus stop.
Take the Nara Kotsu Bus from the JR Yamatoji Line Kamo Station (Kyoto Prefecture) and alight at "Gansenji" bus stop.

sen.j: JR大和路線奈良駅・近鉄奈良駅より奈良交通バス「岩船寺口」下車、徒歩25分
sen.e: Take the Nara Kotsu Bus from JR Yamatoji Line Nara Station or Kintetsu Nara Station, alight at "Gansenji Guchi" bus stop and walk for 25 minutes.
Take the Nara Kotsu Bus from JR Yamatoji Line Nara Station or Kintetsu Nara Station, alight at "Gansenji Guchi" bus stop and walk for 25 minutes.
